post_text:
Check out what these Tigers did last week!

Frenship High School Cross Country and Track paid tribute to men and women who served as First Responders during 9-11.

The two groups split up in teams and run up the home stands a combined 52 times to equal the 110 flights of stairs in the Twin Towers!

‚ÄúWe talked about how everyone played a part, so when we split the students up on teams, they had to decide how they would 'share' the workload," explained Frenship Cross Country Coach Amanda Kirkpatrick. "It was awesome to see them collaborate and then encourage each other to do it!‚Äù

Read more about these outstanding athletes here:https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1298654

post_text:
üëèCheck out this Virtual Learning ROCKSTAR!üëè

Kayci Smith is the Life Training and FOCUS teacher at Frenship High School. This school year she is working to keep her in-person and Virtual Learning students connected.

Smith said Virtual Learning is going well but at times can be challenging. She said she is focused on finding ways to assure Virtual Learning students that they are still part of the Frenship family.

‚ÄúFor my class, we work on social skills, life skills, how to be an advocate for yourself, and real-world situations,‚Äù said Smith. ‚ÄúWith it being virtual, it can be hard at times to get the social aspect going. That is why we are virtually meeting as a class, at least once a week, with my Virtual Learning students. They can see their friends, chat, discuss ALL kinds of things and just build those relationships."
#FrenshipWay

For more info on what Smith is doing click here:
https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1297409

post_text:
How GREAT is this?

South Plains Stars and Shields, a community group that supports local South Plains Law Enforcement, surprised our Frenship Police staff with gift bags and donuts this morning.

Stacy Harvey, one of the organizers of South Plains Stars and Shields, said giving back to Frenship Police has TONS of meaning to her, because her children attended, and are still attending Frenship.

"They do a thank-less job," Harvey said. "I think it's good for the students to have the presence of these men and women just to show that there is someone there if anything goes wrong or if they need help."

üëâThank you Stars and Shields for honoring Frenship Police!

üëâThank you FRENSHIP POLICE for SERVING our schools.

üëâThank you to all first responders...today and always!

post_text:
üêØTake a BITE out of this!üêØ

Frenship's Tiger Bites has ramped up again for this school year! The program provides both federally funded and donation-based food assistance to any child and family in Frenship ISD that may need assistance.

Through weekend food bags, summer feeding programs, Thanksgiving meals, and food assistance during Winter Break, Frenship works with community partners to help serve students in need.

Thank you to Communities In Schools, First Baptist Church of Lubbock, Lakeridge Methodist Church, Calvary Baptist Church, and all of the incredible community partners Frenship is blessed to work with!

#frenshipway

Read more about the program here:
https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1293586

post_text:
üì¢CONGRATULATIONS, Alejandro!üì¢

Frenship Senior Alejandro Gutierrez Fiol has been selected by officials of the National Merit Scholarship Corporation as a Semifinalist in the 66th annual National Merit Scholarship Program.

Last year, Fiol, along with over 1.5 million juniors, entered the 2021 National Merit Scholarship Program by taking the 2019 Preliminary SAT/National Merit Scholarship Qualifying Test, and became a semifinalist along with only about 16,000 other students NATIONWIDE!

Fiol says he is excited for this recognition because he did not think it was possible.

‚ÄúI am very excited about this award because I feel like it can open up a lot of new opportunities for the future that I wouldn‚Äôt have thought were possible just a few years ago,‚Äù Fiol said.

Read more about this INCREDIBLE Frenship Tiger: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1294054

post_text:
üêØCheck out this OUTSTANDING Virtual Teacher!üêØ

Emily Hart teaches Tech Apps, a technology development class, to sixth, seventh and eighth grade virtual students at Terra Vista, and is using her love for curriculum building to aide her in creating a fun, different virtual atmosphere to grow her students computer related skills and better ready them for their futures.

‚ÄúWe decided to give the student a weekly checklist of assignments, so it became more of a self-pace situation,‚Äù said Hart. ‚ÄúWe do have meetings where we log-in every week with TEAMS and I meet with them, but as far as the Monday through Friday, they complete assignments on their own.‚Äù

Read more here: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1292055

post_text:
üëèUPLAND HEIGHTS IS POPPIN'üëè

Last Friday, a few of the AMAZING Upland Heights virtual learning teachers hosted ‚ÄúPoppin‚Äô in for Popsicles,‚Äù a drive-up event for their virtual learning students to drive-up, see their teacher and get a popsicle!

Tara Espindola, 2nd grade virtual learning teacher at Upland Heights, said that the idea for the event started with a quote about Mr. Rogers.

‚ÄúIt started with a quote that was circulating around Facebook,‚Äù Espindola said. ‚ÄúIt said ‚ÄòMr. Rogers was one of the best teachers and he did it virtually.‚Äô So, we thought - if he can do it, we can do it!‚Äù

The group of teachers said that the event was a collective effort and it was the perfect ending to a fun week of dress up days for their virtual learners. They said it was a way for them to be able to celebrate the hard work the students have been doing, and a way to connect with them, engage with them, and let them know that they are still a TIGER!

Great job, ladies! #frenshipway

Read more here: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1291582

What a GREAT example of living the #FrenshipWay!

Upland Heights 5th grade teacher Jacie Studebaker is teaching her virtual learning students how to relate the Frenship SERVE model to every day life, and even how to compare it to their classwork.

‚ÄúWe talk about the SERVE model and how they are still representing that, even in their homes,‚Äù Studebaker said. ‚ÄúWe are also reading ‚ÄòThe One and Only Ivan‚Äô by Katherine Applegate right now, and I will start discussions with them and post questions on their Schoology page to talk about how the characters in the book are displaying the SERVE model.‚Äù

Read more about this Virtual Learning class and how Jacie goes above and beyond here: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1288157

üö®JOB ALERTüö®

Frenship ISD is hiring a District PEIMS Data Coordinator.

This is a District level position. Please help us spread the word and share with anyone who is looking to join our Frenship family!

To apply please visit: https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=760254&type=d&pREC_ID=1166878

üëâDetails Include:
-226 day position
-7 local and 5 state leave days per year
-Salary range: $53,000 - $70,000 (based on experience)
-Bachelor‚Äôs degree (preferred)
-3-5 years of school district administrative support in collecting and entering data
-Experience using coding system
-Ability to maintain accurate and auditable records
-Ability to perform data analysis and problem solve

*Public Education Information Management System (PEIMS)

post_text:
üí°2 DAYS REMAINING for Virtual Learning parents to share their thoughts!!üí°

We want your feedback on how we can stay engaged with you and your student, even from a distance.

Please follow this link:
üëâhttps://my.thoughtexchange.com/#401403102/hub
It will lead you to an open forum to discuss ways you think Frenship can connect better with you and your student.

Here's how it works:
1) This exchange is confidential. Your thoughts will be shared with other participants, but not your identity. You will see and rate other participants' thoughts, with 5 stars meaning agree/important and 1 star meaning disagree/not important.
2) Please be polite and respectful as you share and rate thoughts. Thoughts that are rude or hurtful may be removed from the conversation.
3) You do not need to rate all thoughts in this exchange. It is appreciated and recommended to rate around 20 over the time the exchange is open.

*This link will be live until Friday, September 4, 2020 at 4:30p.m.

post_text:
üí•Awesome Alert!!üí•

Willow Bend Elementary PE coaches Elisa Gonzales and Meagan Vining are finding creative ways amid the pandemic to keep PE fun and engaging, while following state mandates and guidance.

Elisa Gonzales has been coaching PE at Willow Bend for nine years. She said before COVID-19 she would elect captains for each class, and they would be interactive with stop watches, whistles, and other equipment.
She said she felt that this gave the students ownership of the PE class.

However, this year she had to reinvent how to conduct PE to keep kids safe and healthy.

‚ÄúMy goals are to keep class fun,‚Äù Gonzales said, ‚Äúbut to also keep the kids safe.‚Äù

Read More about Coach Gonzales here: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1283485

post_text:
üí°"This is success. A result of perseverance. Full of captured dreams."üí°

Frenship High School revealed their INCubatoredu classroom this week to help kick off the new program for the 2020-2021 school year.

Amy Baker, coordinator of the Career and Technical Education (CTE) program said the room's concept was meant to feel different from all other classrooms.

‚ÄúIn this kind of environment,‚Äù Baker said, ‚Äústudents are encouraged to think beyond a classroom desk or chair, and truly become an innovator or creator.‚Äù

INCubatoredu is a year-long course that will take Frenship students through an elite national business startup model that was developed at Stanford University. Students will create, innovate, and apply their business skills to see an idea through from ideation to creation.

For more info about INCubatoredu: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1151431

post_text:
üêØFrenship Tigers! Join us in CONGRATULATING Haley Kirk and Ida Cisneros!üêØ

We are proud to announce that they are this year‚Äôs Region 17 Elementary Teacher of the Year and Region 17 Secondary Teacher of the year.

Back in May, Kirk and Cisneros were selected as Frenship ISD‚Äôs Elementary and Secondary Teachers of the Year, landing them spots in the regional competition with other teachers across dozens of districts.

Now as the Region 17 2021 Elementary and Secondary Teachers of the Year, they will be in the running to be the Texas Elementary and Secondary Teachers of the Year along with the other regional award recipients.

Kirk is a 5th grade science teacher at Westwind Elementary and Cisneros is an RLA teacher at Frenship Middle School.

While this is the third year in a row that a Frenship teacher has earned the prestigious award, it is the first time in Frenship history that Frenship teachers have been selected for both awards.

Read more about Kirk and Cisneos here: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1276569

Frenship Middle School welcomes Rebecca Whipkey as a new Assistant Principal! She is transitioning from being an Instructional Math Coach for FMS and Terra Vista Middle School.

Whipkey grew up in Sudan, TX and went on to earn her bachelor‚Äôs degree at Texas A&M University. She is currently working on completing her master‚Äôs degree in Educational Leadership from the University of Texas at Arlington. She has been with Frenship ISD for 17 years!!

‚ÄúI am looking forward to seeing how our staff grows our students academically, emotionally, and socially this year,‚Äù said Whipkey. ‚ÄúFMS is a great place to be and I am thrilled to be a part of such an amazing staff.‚Äù

üëâRead more about Rebecca here:
https://fms.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1276455

post_text:
üêØHappy #feelgoodfriday Tigers!üêØ

As Frenship ISD prepares for the upcoming school year, providing the cleanest environment for students, teachers and staff is top priority.

Cecil Flores, FISD Custodial Services Operation Manager, is helping train custodians and staff to do just that.

Flores said the children, staff, visitors and the FISD team are the main reasons for all the new cleaning, disinfecting, and sanitizing improvements. While COVID-19 has expedited these changes, our Frenship families are the main concern.

‚ÄúThese are not just students; these are our children,‚Äù said Flores. ‚ÄúWe have to take care of them.‚Äù

Beyond hiring additional custodial staff, FISD added a Quality Assurance Custodian (QAC) to each campus. The QAC will ensure the building is sanitized and disinfected to the standards set forth by the district.

Read more here:https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1274094

üç¥DON'T FORGET!!üç¥

Frenship families, you still have time to apply for the Pandemic -EBT food benefits. The deadline has been extended to AUGUST 21.

Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) provides eligible families with a one-time payment for each child who previously received free or reduced-price meals. P-EBT works the same way Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits do and will help families get the food they need during the current pandemic.

CLICK HERE TO APPLY: https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=760005&type=d&pREC_ID=1166598

post_text:
üí°Happy #motivationmonday üí°

On Friday, August 7 Frenship hosted the sixth annual West Texas Innovation Summit that was focused on educating during a pandemic.

During the summit, attendees heard from keynote speaker John Antonetti through a recorded keynote address and were also given the opportunity to learn from their fellow educators.

Frenship High School Career and Technical Education (CTE) Coordinator, Amy Baker, led a breakout session entitled ‚ÄúBuilding Relationships During Distance Learning and Social Distancing.‚Äù

‚ÄúParents, teachers, and students will be able to work together to foster learning and expand potential,‚Äù said Baker. ‚ÄúTeachers will grow, students will progress, and the Frenship Way will continue to guide our hearts and actions. All the things that make Frenship special will continue to shine regardless of how or where our children learn.‚Äù

Read more about Innovation Summit here:
https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1269867
text:
üí°Happy #motivationmonday üí°

On Friday, August 7 Frenship hosted the sixth annual West Texas Innovation Summit that was focused on educating during a pandemic.

During the summit, attendees heard from keynote speaker John Antonetti through a recorded keynote address and were also given the opportunity to learn from their fellow educators.

Frenship High School Career and Technical Education (CTE) Coordinator, Amy Baker, led a breakout session entitled ‚ÄúBuilding Relationships During Distance Learning and Social Distancing.‚Äù

‚ÄúParents, teachers, and students will be able to work together to foster learning and expand potential,‚Äù said Baker. ‚ÄúTeachers will grow, students will progress, and the Frenship Way will continue to guide our hearts and actions. All the things that make Frenship special will continue to shine regardless of how or where our children learn.‚Äù

Read more about Innovation Summit here:
https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1269867

post_text:
We had a great time at United Supermarket‚Äôs 9th Annual Back to School Supply Drive kickoff this week!

Along with five other local school districts, Frenship Superintendent, Dr. Michelle McCord, was given a $100 United Supermarket gift card to shop for school supplies that will later be donated.

Dr. McCord said that this year it will be even more important for the community to help students receive school supplies because many families are facing hardship caused by the ongoing pandemic.

‚ÄúWe have such a supportive community,‚Äù McCord said. ‚ÄúWe know they are going to lift us up and stand behind us to make sure that every kiddo gets a great start.‚Äù

In previous years, United has allowed purchased school supplies to be donated at each location in a designated bin, however due to COVID-19, this year United will only be accepting monetary donations.

Read more about the Back to School Supplies Drive here:
https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1264197

post_text:
Join us in congratulating Heritage Middle School Principal Chelsey Campbell for being awarded Texas Association of Secondary School Principals Region 17 Middle School Principal of the Year.

Campbell was selected from tons of other outstanding principals and assistant principals from each of the twenty TASSP regions!

‚ÄúTo be honest I was completely shocked,‚Äù said Campbell. ‚ÄúThere are so many incredible administrators that I am lucky to work with in this region. I am humbled by the recognition and know that credit goes to my incredible staff, students, and the leaders I have had the opportunity to learn from.‚Äù

Campbell is starting her third year with FISD and has been in education for 15 years. She said HMS is a blessing to her in many ways, and that she is humbled to serve alongside the rest of her staff.

Read more about Chelsey here:https://hms.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1263185

üç¥APPLICATION DEADLINE EXTENDED!üç¥

Frenship families, you still have time to apply for the Pandemic -EBT food benefits. The deadline has been extended to AUGUST 21.

Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) provides eligible families with a one-time payment for each child who previously received free or reduced-price meals. P-EBT works the same way Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits do and will help families get the food they need during the current pandemic.

CLICK HERE TO APPLY: https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=760005&type=d&pREC_ID=1166598 See Less

post_text:
Frenship families,

We know you have tough decisions to make about the upcoming school year. Every family situation is different. We will do our best to support our families and their needs.

We have been working to develop options for our students while also implementing new and changing mandates, requirements, and guidance from the State. But through it all - Frenship remains committed to providing a premier learning environment for all students where our teachers take pride in meeting the needs of every student to empower them to reach their potential.

We know it's a lot of information, but please take the time to read through our Reopening Parent Guide and website FAQs. We fully understand that you will still have questions as we continue working through this process. Give us a call/email and we will work to answer your concerns.

WATCH: Check out this quick message from Superintendent Dr. Michelle McCord:
https://youtu.be/uqWkEnSVBDA

post_text:
Please join us in congratulating Kelsey Taylor on her new role as Assistant Principal at the FHS Ninth Grade Center. She is transitioning from FHS where she taught English for nine years.

Taylor has been a Tiger since she attended Kindergarten at Casey Elementary! She graduated from FHS in 2006, moved onto Texas Tech University to earn a bachelor‚Äôs degree in English, and completed her education at Wayland Baptist University with a Master‚Äôs in Educational Leadership.

During her time at teaching FHS, Taylor also helped coach and support fellow teachers in her role as the English Department Chair and earned multiple awards for her excellence, including FHS Teacher of the Year and the Beaumont Excellence in Education award!

‚ÄúI look forward to serving the Frenship community through these difficult times,‚Äù said Taylor. ‚ÄúI welcome that challenge, and I am excited to work with our 9GC team to meet the needs of our freshmen this year.‚Äù

Read more about Kelsey here:
https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1259741

post_text:
Today the University Interscholastic League (UIL) released new guidelines impacting Fall UIL athletic and band activities. Based on the newly released UIL schedules, Frenship athletics and marching band can begin official UIL practices on September 7, pushing back the season timeline. Frenship coaches and band instructors are currently working to adjust practice, game, and contest schedules to align with the new UIL guidance.

Frenship will continue closely monitoring UIL, the Texas Education Agency (TEA), Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and State of Texas for any additional changes and requirements. We appreciate our Frenship families and their patience as we sort through the details.

Additional information related to Frenship UIL activities will be released as soon it becomes available. To read the new UIL guidance including athletic and band schedules, spectator updates, and more click here: https://www.uiltexas.org/policy/covid-19

Recently Governor Abbott released information on reopening schools across Texas. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, Frenship ISD is currently working on a plan to offer two instructional options for the 2020-2021 school year that will begin on August 17.

The two options include in person Face-to-Face Instruction and Virtual Learning.

We plan to send out detailed information on the instructional options and reopening plan next week on July 24. That information will be communicated directly to parents through a Skyward email, on the Frenship website (link below üëá), and on our social media pages.

Frenship Reopening web page: https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/reopeningfrenship

post_text:
**REOPENING PLAN**

Frenship families, we know you have a lot of questions about returning to school in August. Frenship ISD is currently reviewing new guidance and requirements set by the Texas Education Agency (TEA) and State of Texas on reopening for the 2020-2021 school year. Based on that guidance, Frenship is working to customize a plan specific to our district. This will include changes to safety and health protocols, enhanced cleaning procedures, and operational and instructional adjustments. Over the next two weeks, Frenship will continue developing and finalizing a plan that will be released to parents and the public on July 24.

We appreciate your patience as we sort through the details to create a plan to safely reopen Frenship.

post_text:
*UIL CHANGES*

Frenship families, UIL has just released new guidance for our summer athletic and marching band workouts and practices including requirements for face coverings.

All staff, parents, visitors, and students age ten and older must wear a face covering when entering and exiting facilities or practice areas where UIL activities are being conducted and when they're not actively exercising or practicing.

This means Frenship students participating in our athletic and band summer UIL activities must have a face covering when we resume practices and workouts on Monday, July 13.

You can read more about the new UIL requirements here: https://www.uiltexas.org/covid-19-information

APPLICATION DEADLINE EXTENDED!

Frenship families, you still have time to apply for the Pandemic -EBT food benefits. The deadline has been extended to July 31.

Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) provides eligible families with a one-time payment for each child who previously received free or reduced-price meals. P-EBT works the same way Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits do and will help families get the food they need during the current pandemic.

CLICK HERE TO APPLY: https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=760005&type=d&pREC_ID=1166598

"They know I have an open door policy at my office. They know they're welcome in there at anytime, and they know they can come in and talk about anything," said FHS Auto Tech teacher Dana Vinson. "The big thing for me is I want to develop personal relationships."

We love everything about this story! Mr. Vinson is one of those teachers that his students never forget. It's no surprise that he was chosen as the Texas PTA Secondary Teacher of the Year!

Mr. Vinson, thank you for truly caring about our students and their success! We are proud to call you a Frenship Tiger!

WATCH HERE:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vBvhCGA4LfU&feature=youtu.be

post_text:
Alright folks, we have more GREAT news!

Please welcome another new Frenship tiger! Brandy Copeland has been selected as the new principal for Westwind Elementary. She is a Snyder, Texas native who has spent the past 16 years serving Midland ISD.

During those 16 years in education, seven have been in leadership roles as a principal or assistant principal. We're excited to gain a great leader, but don't take our word for it...one of her past awards includes being selected as the Region 18 Assistant Principal of the Year!

‚ÄúI am beyond excited to have the opportunity to be a part of the Frenship ISD family and even more so with my new Westwind Elementary family,‚Äù said Copeland. ‚ÄúI feel blessed and honored to be able to work with such strong leadership and look forward to linking arms with my new team and helping students and staff continue to improve and achieve our goals together.‚Äù

Read more about the new principal here: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1247596

post_text:
Please help us congratulate our newest school board member, Andrew Cox! During tonight's school board meeting, the Frenship ISD Board of Trustees voted unanimously to appoint Cox to fill the Place 2 vacancy on the board.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm excited for the opportunity to be part of the board, this school district, the growth, and the potential for Frenship. I‚Äôm hoping to learn a lot and continue the great work of the board members who have laid the road map for Frenship‚Äôs success," said Cox.

Cox, a Lubbock native, has been married to his wife Susan for nearly 20 years. Their three children attend Frenship at Terra Vista Middle School and Legacy Elementary.

We would also like to extend our appreciation to Brandon Autrey for his service to the Frenship community. After two and half years as a board member, Autrey and his family are relocating to his hometown in New Mexico.

Read more here: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1247060

"It‚Äôs great to get back, at least for us, to what seems normal even though we‚Äôve had to make some adjustments. It's really great to see everybody, to be back together, and get some work in." - Coach Northcutt

After WEEKS of preparing and planning workouts aligning with the new UIL and CDC guidelines, students are back! Frenship's athletic UIL summer camps started this week. While it might not look the same as last summer, Coach Northcutt says the changes are there for a good reason.

"It‚Äôs important to limit the risk from a safety aspect, and it‚Äôs important to follow those guidelines so we can continue to open up," he said.

post_text:
Frenship families,

Some of you may be eligible for the Pandemic-EBT food benefits.

WHO SHOULD APPLY:
Families who received SNAP benefits for the month of March 2020 and have children 5-18 years old as of May 17, 2020, do not need to apply for those children. These families should have received P-EBT benefits on their current Lone Star Card by May 22.

Families with children up to 21 years old who are certified to receive free or reduced-price meals during the 2019-20 school year need to apply for P-EBT. (This includes families who received SNAP benefits for the month of March 2020 and have children under 5 and between 19 and 21.) Once HHSC receives the application and verifies your eligibility with the school list, you will receive a Texas P-EBT card in the mail that includes P-EBT funds.

To apply, click here: https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=760005&type=d&pREC_ID=1166598

Families with children up to 21 years old who are certified to receive free or reduced-price meals during the 2019-20 school year need to apply for P-EBT. (This includes families who received SNAP benefits for the month of March 2020 and have children under 5 and between 19 and 21.) post_text:
TODAY IS THE DAY!!!

Seniors, it's been a wild year. We know it's not how you wanted to wrap up your time at Frenship. Some of you didn't get to step foot on the field or court to compete in your last year of sports. Others missed their opportunity to shine on stage during theater productions. There were many who earned a spot at state competitions - but never got to show their amazing skills and knowledge. There were missed opportunities, missed memories, and missed celebrations.

We know.

We also know you are a resilient group of students who continue to make us proud - even at a distance. We know your determination and fortitude has prepared you for the real word. You desire to live the Frenship Way has made you into men and women that we are proud to call Frenship Tigers. Tonight it will look and feel different, but we hope YOU know how excited we are to celebrate your accomplishments and hard work.

WATCH LIVE HERE: https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1140531&type=d&pREC_ID=1812728

post_text:
Frenship Tigers!

After approval by UIL, Frenship will begin Summer UIL camps on Monday, June 8. This includes strength and conditioning and sport specific instruction.

Students and parents will see many changes this year as we adhere to new UIL requirements and guidance from the State of Texas, Texas Education Agency, and CDC. This includes limiting the number of students allowed inside facilities, designated entrances and exits to avoid crowding, smaller group sizes to limit contact between athletes, and cleaning procedures.

To read more about the UIL summer camps, protocols, restrictions, participant requirements and expectations, CLICK HERE:
https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/SummerCamps

post_text:
Tomorrow is the BIG day for our FHS 2020 Seniors!

Have family and friends that can't attend? Planning on hosting a graduation watch party? Do you have family members out of state that want to tune in?

We have you covered! Whether it's from your phone, tablet, computer, or smart TV, we have many ways you can watch the ceremony LIVE.

- Frenship.TV
- Here on the Frenship Facebook Page
- Frenship Twitter Page
- Through the BoxCast App on AppleTV, Roku, and FireTV
- Fox 34's My Lubbock TV channel

We will also post the recording in its entirety (with photos added of the graduates who can't attend) to our website after the ceremony so you can watch it again and share the video with loved ones!

Ways to Watch: https://fhs.frenship.net/apps/pages/watchgraduation

Direct Link to Live Stream: https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1140531&type=d&pREC_ID=1812728

post_text:
We LOVE how something as simple as a box of chalk can bring a family AND neighborhood together! If you haven't seen the house with the INCREDIBLE chalk art out front, it's a must see... and it's done by none other than our very own Marietta Decker, a Frenship High School business and technology teacher.

At a time when so many people have been isolated during this pandemic, her family's artwork has made people - complete strangers - feel connected! üíô

During the interview she said, "We've met so many people, and we've talked to so many people, neighbors that we hadn't met before. We love that. We love that we can bring a little smile to someone's face!"

See her amazing artwork for yourself: https://youtu.be/VBHzwFS7u1M

(And thanks to Ray Rush, FHS Broadcast Media teacher, who put this story together!)

YOUTUBE.COM

Frenship High School
June 2 at 2:45 PM ¬∑

We are almost there! In three days, our seniors will be walking across the stage!

Due to COVID-19, we've had to limit the guests to four people per senior. That means each guest, regardless of age, MUST present a ticket at the stadium gates or they will not be allowed to enter.

If you missed the ticket pick up days last week, give us a call so we can coordinate a pickup time.

üö®Pick Up Requirements:
- Each senior will receive four tickets for guests
- Only the student graduating or the primary guardian listed in Skyward can pick up the tickets
- IDs will be required for pick up

post_text: Congratulations, Noble! We are proud to call you a tiger!
shared_text:
Frenship Athletics
May 30 at 1:10 PM ¬∑

This morning, Noble Robinson signed to play basketball at Clarendon College and became Frenship's 40th signee of 2019-2020! Noble started over 65 games for Tiger Basketball as a three-year varsity player. Way to go Noble! ‚ÄúHe played a big role in our success this year.‚Äù ‚ÄúHe averaged over three assists per game which says a lot about the type of player he was.‚Äù ‚ÄúHe likes to lead," Said Head Coach Paul Page. #TigerPride #FrenshipNation #AlwaysATiger

Over the past few months, we learned a lot about remote learning and educating our students at a distance. It was a new experience for all of us - teachers, parents, and students. At Frenship, we are always seeking to improve the ways we serve our families, and that's why we want to hear from you.

post_text:
Frenship families,

Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) is a one-time food benefit for families who lost access to free or reduced-price meals due to school closures. Eligible P-EBT families will receive application instructions from our District in late May. The P-EBT application will open the first week of June.

P-EBT food benefits are for children who received SNAP food benefits for March 2020 and children who are certified for free or reduced-price school meals during the 2019-20 Texas school year.

For more information, visit: hhs.texas.gov/PEBT

post_text:
CHANGES TO CURBSIDE MEALS:

Frenship ISD and Aramark will continue to provide curbside meals at no cost to the children in the community until further notice. Families will be able to pick up breakfast and lunch for all seven days of the week. Meals are available for all children age 18 or younger, and they do not have to be a Frenship student.

Below are changes for the summer curbside meals:

**On Monday, May 25, there will be no curbside meals due to the Memorial Day holiday.

Starting Thursday, May 28, pickup days will change to Tuesdays and Thursdays at only two locations. On Tuesdays, families will pick up breakfast and lunch for Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday. On Thursdays, families will pick up breakfast and lunch for Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday.

Pickup Times: Tuesdays and Thursdays from 12:00 p.m. to 1:30 p.m.

Pickup Locations:
- Frenship Ninth Grade Center - 407 North Dowden Road, Wolfforth, TX
- Westwind Elementary ‚Äì 6401 43rd Street, Lubbock, TX

Since March 23, Frenship and Aramark have proudly served more than 200,000 meals to children in our community.

post_text:
As we honor our seniors' accomplishments today, we have one more post for you.... and it's a good one. These students have set the bar high. Out of more than 600 seniors, we present to you the top ten academic students for the Class of 2020! During a drive-thru ceremony, we were able to personally congratulate them on this incredible honor of academic excellence! We can't wait to see you all at graduation! #16Days

Emmeline Davila - Valedictorian
Addison Wall - Salutatorian
Ava Chaparro - 3rd in her class
Hilary Johnson - 4th in her class
Joshua Salisbury - 5th in his class
Reagan Hardy - 6th in her class
Tanner Higgins - 7th in his class
Ahmad Altabaa - 8th in his class (Not pictured)
Thompson Nguyen - 9th in his class
Reagan Erculiani - 10th in her class

Surrounded by their family members, we had TEN seniors commit to compete at the collegiate level including Texas Tech cheer, Abilene Christian track, FIVE for Lubbock Christian track, Odessa College dance, and WTAMU dance!

Congratulations, seniors! We are proud to call you Tigers!

Members of the Wolfforth Masonic Lodge came out to present them each with a $1,500 scholarship to go toward their college education next year!

post_text:
Frenship families, get ready. We're about to flood your Facebook feed with accomplishments by our Class of 2020 seniors!

First up, Alli Ferguson! This FHS senior made history for both Frenship and Wayland Baptist University when she signed her letter of intent to play esports at the collegiate level.

Alli was part of Frenship High School's first esports team. The program kicked off this year, and was a huge success, coming in 2nd place in the STATE for Rocket League. Alli is the first Frenship student to sign with a college to play esports.

If that wasn't cool enough, Alli is also the first female to earn a spot on Wayland's team! Congratulations, Alli! We are proud to call you a Frenship Tiger!

The Frenship Tigers you see in this video were chosen as the Support Professional of the Year, Rookie Teacher of the Year, or Teacher of the Year for their respective campus.

Normally, we would recognize them during the annual Staff Appreciation banquet. Since it was cancelled this year, please help us show them some love for all of their hard work!

As we wrap up the last week of remote learning, we want to hear from YOU about the remote learning experience.

During the COVID-19 pandemic, we have learned a lot about remote learning as a means for educating children. Frenship ISD always seeks to improve the ways we serve our families, so we need your help in understanding how we can improve.

post_text:
These men and women will truly be missed across our District! We have 12 teachers and staff members retiring at the end of the school year. Due to COVID-19 and the closures, they won't get the chance to say goodbye to their students and peers this week.

We know it's not the ending they had hoped for, but here at Frenship, we couldn't just let them leave without a proper farewell! Despite the rain last week, we held curbside celebrations for each of the May retirees. It gave them a chance to wave and say goodbye at a distance to teachers and students who drove by, and it allowed us to properly thank them for their years of service and dedication!

Since we didn't get to host our Staff Appreciation banquet, Texas Tech Credit Union stepped up and made a donation so these May retirees could still go out and enjoy a nice dinner.

From all of us at Frenship, thank you and good luck on your next adventure!

post_text:
Who needs a sweet story to kick off their weekend?!

Embracing remote learning, our teachers have come up with some unique lessons and activities. This is definitely one of our favorites! Several weeks ago, students in Mrs. Barnett's FHS Mentor Program were tasked with creating notes and encouraging messages for some of our local senior citizens. When all was said and done, students had created more than 100 photos and notes that were printed and delivered to Villa Residential Care of Wolfforth!

We know it's been difficult for the residents to not have visitors, but hopefully the notes and photos put a smile on their faces! Thanks Mrs. Barnett and Frenship Mentor students for living the #FrenshipWay!

Each year, we host a Superintendent's Academic Excellence banquet to honor the Frenship High School top ten academic students in the sophomore, junior, and senior classes. Unfortunately, we were unable to hold a formal banquet due to COVID-19, but we still want to honor and recognize their achievements and success.

In addition to the video, we will be holding a Superintendent's Academic Excellence Drive-Thru Ceremony tonight to personally congratulate and thank each of these FHS students for setting a standard of excellence for their peers.

Congratulations, students!

post_text:
As we celebrate National Police Week, please help us give a big THANK YOU to our Frenship police officers and security guards! They work at our schools because they truly care about our students and enjoy being around them! But their service goes beyond the badge.

They greet students with a big smile and high five as they help them cross the street, they chat with students as they walk the hallways, they volunteer to brighten a child's day by delivering toys or reading to a class, they've helped at curbside meals, they're the students' biggest fans as they cheer them on at school and athletic events... they do A LOT, and we could not be more proud to call his group our very own!

#NationalPoliceWeek #PoliceWeek2020

post_text:
#TeacherAppreciationWeek
"I just appreciate how you breathe life into them and feed them with wisdom and knowledge. I can't imagine doing what you do, and we're just so thankful and appreciative of all of you - each and every one of you. So thank you from our household." - Kimberly Bengoa, mother of four Frenship students.

Thank you, Bengoa Family, for sharing your experience and for your kind words to our teachers! The reality is that not every day will be a good day. That's okay. This is new to all of us, and no one is perfect. But what we do know - we love our students, we continue to support our families in any way we can, and we will work through this as a community!

As we celebrate Teacher Appreciation Week, we want to honor these two very special teachers! Biology teacher Heather Walls at the FHS Ninth Grade Center - Frenship ISD and kindergarten - 5th grade math intervention teacher Barbara Young at Westwind Elementary - Frenship ISD are recipients of the 2020 Beaumont Foundation Frank & Nancy Newton Excellence in Education Award.

This prestigious award recognizes the best of the best and celebrates teachers who have made extraordinary contributions and impacts on their students and peers. We are SO proud to have them in our Frenship family!

Read more about each teacher here: http://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1224505

#TeacherAppreciationWeek

If you haven't seen this video, it's a MUST watch! Our very own Aaron Parrish was featured on KLBK News - EverythingLubbock.com as the Teacher of the Week. Mr. Parrish is a kindergarten and first grade Life Skills teacher at Bennett Elementary - Frenship ISD.

In the video, he sings one of his songs he wrote for his students! We love his enthusiasm for teaching and connecting with his students!

He also has a special message for parents: "There are so many teachers out there working their tails off to keep their students engaged during these unpredictable times, and the endless list of people who deserve this award does not stop in the classroom. So, I would like to thank all the parents for their continued support and for working with your precious children at home." - Aaron Parrish

shared_text:

Teacher of the Week goes to ‚Ä¶ Aaron Parrish
text:
#TeacherAppreciationWeek

If you haven't seen this video, it's a MUST watch! Our very own Aaron Parrish was featured on KLBK News - EverythingLubbock.com as the Teacher of the Week. Mr. Parrish is a kindergarten and first grade Life Skills teacher at Bennett Elementary - Frenship ISD.

In the video, he sings one of his songs he wrote for his students! We love his enthusiasm for teaching and connecting with his students!

He also has a special message for parents: "There are so many teachers out there working their tails off to keep their students engaged during these unpredictable times, and the endless list of people who deserve this award does not stop in the classroom. So, I would like to thank all the parents for their continued support and for working with your precious children at home." - Aaron Parrish

post_text:
For Teacher Appreciation Week, we would like to honor the hundreds of men and women at Frenship who have dedicated their lives to enriching, empowering, and equipping our future. Teachers, your love and passion for your students has become even more evident over the last few months. Thank you for adapting and finding new ways to impact your students.

#TeacherAppreciationWeek
shared_text:
Teachers Can
April 13 at 9:26 AM ¬∑

The very reason teachers choose their profession ‚Äî their desire to put their students before themselves ‚Äî also precludes them from taking credit for the lifelong difference they make for those students. If this point in time has revealed anything, it is just how incredible and important teachers are.

Teachers Can is a partnership of dozens of businesses, associations, community organizations, and universities who believe that, now more than ever, teachers deserve to own their impact. And that teachers deserve to hear from all of us how valuable they are to our students, our families, our communities, and our future.

Please share this video, for those who can, for those who teach. Then visit TeachersCan.org to find more ways to thank our teachers. #TeachersCan

Today is School Lunch Hero Day, and we have to say, Aramark and our cafeteria staff are truly heroes!üíô

In five weeks, we have served more than 100,000 curbside meals to children in the community, and we could not have done it with out their help! Despite the long hours, coming in on weekends, and the constant changes due to COVID-19, the Aramark staff have gone above and beyond to keep one thing constant - children have food to eat.

Please help us thank our #SchoolLunchHeroes!

Congratulations to the Outreach Raiders with the Texas Tech University - Whitacre College of Engineering for receiving the TTU award for Outstanding Contribution to the Greater Community! These Tech students share their love of engineering to foster and cultivate that same passion in young elementary students. Many of our Frenship students take part in their Junior Engineers club and they LOVE getting to interact with the Outreach Raiders! We are so thankful for this partnership and for their dedication to mentoring our students!

post_text:
It's stories like these that keep us going and remind us why it's so important to live the #FrenshipWay.

Back in February we shared a sweet story about the Superintendent's Student Advisory Board. Each year, Superintendent Dr. McCord and the high school students join together to make blankets as a community service project. This year the blankets were donated to the UMC Cancer Center.

This week, UMC Health System sent us this special card with an update on one of the blankets used by a patient. In part, the card read, "She was nervous about her treatment. When presented with the blanket by one of our nurses, she was touched. I saw her shoulders relax as she rubbed her hands over it."

UMC also created a card that says "Made with Love" to pin to each blanket.

We are so proud of our students! #SpreadKindness, even if it's a small act, you never know how big of an impact it will have on someone.

CURBSIDE MEAL REMINDER:

There will NOT be curbside meal pickup today (Wednesday, April 29). The meal pickup days have been changed to Mondays & Thursdays now that Frenship & Aramark are providing meals for all seven days of the week.

But while we're on the subject, we want to give a BIG shout out to Atmos Energy. Since the beginning of our curbside meal distribution, they have sent volunteers to help at all six curbside meal locations each pickup day. From handing out the food to filling the bags, they have helped in a tremendous way!

From all of us at Frenship, thank you for supporting our community and showing that you care for our families!

#FrenshipWay #SpreadKindness

We absolutely LOVE seeing how our students continue to live the Frenship Way outside the classroom! Thank you, Emmanuel, for spreading kindness during this time! üíô

From North Ridge Elementary - Frenship ISD: North Ridge Kindergarten student Emmanuel Coulombe and his family are showing what it means to exemplify the Frenship Way. Emmanuel and his mom are providing food for 2 nurse units. A portion of Emmanuel‚Äôs school day is spent cooking and helping with delivery of food to the nurses. Exerting kindness and teaching life lessons while being at home is the Frenship Way. Thank you to this little tiger and his family for giving back to our community!

post_text:
Here's a #MondayMotivation to get your week started! The last two months have been a challenge, but our teachers, parents and students have shown so much grace as we work through this new process.

One of the things we've LOVED getting to see, is all the unique and special ways teachers are staying connected to their students. Chalking sidewalks with sweet messages, coaches driving by to check on their athletes (at a distance of course), creating music videos to keep learning fun, driveway story time .... the list goes on!

Thank you Kasie Davis KCBD for highlighting one of the many examples of how our Frenship families are sticking together!

WATCH VIDEO: https://www.kcbd.com/2020/04/23/westwind-elementary-teacher-connects-with-students-unique-way-while-adhering-social-distancing-guidelines/

post_text:
üç¥ Frenship ISD & Aramark to Offer Meals for Seven Days a Weeküç¥

Since March 23, Frenship and Aramark have proudly served more than 109,000 meals to children in our community! And starting next Monday, April 27, we will increase the number of meals provided at no cost to children in the community. Families will now be able to pick up breakfast and lunch for all seven days of the week. Meals are available for all children age 18 or younger, and they do not have to be a Frenship student.

With the increase of meals, the pickup days have changed to Mondays and Thursday each week.

On Mondays, each child will receive meals for Monday through Wednesday of that week. On Thursdays, each child will receive meals for Thursday through Sunday of that week.

üö®NEW Pickup Times: Mondays and Thursdays from 12:00 p.m. to 1:30 p.m. üö®

Six Pick Up Locations will remain the same:

FHS Ninth Grade Center - Frenship ISD
Terra Vista Middle School - Frenship ISD
Legacy Elementary - Frenship ISD
North Ridge Elementary - Frenship ISD
Westwind Elementary - Frenship ISD
Willow Bend Elementary - Frenship ISD

post_text:
Frenship Seniors & Parents,

Since the Governor announced on Friday that schools will stay closed for the remainder of the school year, we have been getting many questions concerning the Frenship High School graduation ceremony.

We know there has been a lot of uncertainty about graduation. Getting to walk across the stage is a milestone for our students and one they deserve.

At this time, a decision has not been made to postpone the graduation ceremony on May 22nd. We are closely monitoring the current situation including restrictions on gatherings and social distancing guidelines. Over the next few weeks, Frenship will work with local and state government officials and healthcare professionals on how to move forward.

We promise to keep you updated with the latest information.

post_text:
In Lubbock County, an average of 3 children per day become confirmed victims of abuse and neglect. Other victims exist but go unreported each day.

For National Child Abuse Prevention Month, our Frenship staff members are joining the Go Blue Lubbock campaign! Each Friday, we will wear our blue to help raise awareness. We will also share resources to help our Frenship community recognize the warning signs, information on how to report abuse, and much more. On our Social Emotional Resources page you will find a section dedicated to learning more about child abuse.

#GoBlueLubbock

Click for Information: https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1702892&type=d&pREC_ID=1871918

Today Texas Governor Greg Abbott announced that all Texas schools will remain closed through the end of the school year due to COVID-19 as part of a new executive order. This means campuses will remain closed, but instruction through remote learning will continue through May 21 for Frenship ISD.

While we are saddened that we won‚Äôt get to see our students in classrooms again this school year, we know this decision is best for the health and well-being of every student and family. Frenship ISD will continue to support you in every way possible during this time.

We will communicate more information soon. To see the latest information, head over to our COVID-19 page: https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1702892&type=d&pREC_ID=1844819

Frenship High School
April 16 at 12:50 PM ¬∑

Congratulations to FHS Support Staff of the Year ‚Äì Ricky De La Garza
‚Ä¢ Mr. De La Garza is not a teaching aide, not an ISS aide, nor one of our secretaries. Ricky is on the maintenance staff that was assigned to FHS campus well into the school year. FHS has more square feet than the South Plains mall and for most people it would be an overwhelming task to ensure everything is up and running. You can find Ricky in the hallways, out on the grounds, or in an empty classroom with a positive demeanor and can-do attitude making sure all is working properly. We are lucky to have Ricky working at FHS!

The campus libraries are closed, but that doesn't mean story time has to end! We love how Willow Bend Elementary - Frenship ISD Librarian/ Media Specialist Darby Pilgrim is still reading to students through a virtual story time!

And did you know, Mrs. Pilgrim was recently chosen to be part of the Bluebonnet Selection Committee? As part of the committee, she will read HUNDREDS of books this year to help select books that reflect student interest, content, reputable reviews, and literary quality for Grade 3-6!

AND did you know, April is School Library Month?! A big THANK YOU to all of our librarians like Mrs. Pilgrim who help ignite a passion for reading in our students!

The online remote learning packets for this week are now up! Your student can work directly off the packets online with clickable links for additional activities/videos, or you can download the packet and save it to your computer. Printing is optional.

Some changes you'll notice:
- Grade levels Pre-K through 8 across the District have the same instructional material, regardless of what campus students attend. (For grades 9-12, instructional packets will be individualized based on the courses students are enrolled in.)
- We have added elective and/or specials into this single packet to condense the number of packets a student will receive.
- You will only be receiving one week of instruction at a time.

post_text:
üëè THISüëè

This is what it means to live the #FrenshipWay

Frenship High School Engineering teacher and robotics coach James Holloway decided to give his students a project during remote learning - create, design, or build something that could help our community during the COVID-19 crisis. Awesome, right?! The kids can take what they're learning at school and use it to help in a real world situation!

FHS student Mark Dannemiller took the project to heart! Using a ventilator prototype, he enhanced the design to also make it a respirator for patients fighting COVID-19. He is currently in talks with local medical facilities to provide them with the final product design. AND this is something he's sharing with other high school/robotics teams around the country to see if they want to get involved!

"He‚Äôs really what Frenship is about and he‚Äôs really what our future is about.‚Äù - Mr. Holloway.

WATCH THE STORY:
shared_text:
KCBD.COM
Frenship High School student develops respirator for COVID-19 patients

KCBD NewsChannel 11
April 7 at 7:11 PM ¬∑

After an assigned project by his engineering teacher and robotics team coach amid distance learning, 17-year-old Mark Dannemiller was determined to figure out a way to help those suffering from the virus.

üëè THISüëè

This is what it means to live the #FrenshipWay

Frenship High School Engineering teacher and robotics coach James Holloway decided to give his students a project during remote learning - create, design, or build something that could help our community during the COVID-19 crisis. Awesome, right?! The kids can take what they're learning at school and use it to help in a real world situation!

FHS student Mark Dannemiller took the project to heart! Using a ventilator prototype, he enhanced the design to also make it a respirator for patients fighting COVID-19. He is currently in talks with local medical facilities to provide them with the final product design. AND this is something he's sharing with other high school/robotics teams around the country to see if they want to get involved!

"He‚Äôs really what Frenship is about and he‚Äôs really what our future is about.‚Äù - Mr. Holloway.

WATCH THE STORY:

KCBD.COM
Frenship High School student develops respirator for COVID-19 patients

KCBD NewsChannel 11
April 7 at 7:11 PM ¬∑

After an assigned project by his engineering teacher and robotics team coach amid distance learning, 17-year-old Mark Dannemiller was determined to figure out a way to help those suffering from the virus.

post_text:
Talk about a #MondayMotivation! We love seeing our students do amazing things, even if they can't be here physically!

As part of their remote learning, Frenship High School engineering students were tasked with a project to design or create something that could help our communities during the pandemic.

FHS student Mark Dannemiller has been working to modify an open source design from MIT on a portable respirator or simplified ventilator, that will compress an Ambu bag on a patient. He's working with the Texas Tech University - Whitacre College of Engineering to help with engineering the parts. So proud of our Tigers!

#FrenshipWay
#SeekPerfection #CaptureExcellence

post_text:
Frenship Families,
You may have just heard, Texas Governor Greg Abbott announced that all Texas schools will remain closed through Friday, May 1 due to COVID-19. This means Frenship schools will remain closed, but instruction through remote learning will continue. This decision is based on the social distancing guidelines in effect through the month of April as advised by federal, state and local officials.

During this closure, we will continue to support our Frenship families in every way possible. That includes providing curbside meals at our six locations for all children 18 and younger through the extended closure.

We appreciate your patience and support during this time. Our time apart has been extended, but we are still in this together.
You can check out more resources for technology, remote learning FAQs, social emotional learning activities and much more at: www.frenship.net

post_text:
Frenship Families,

Yesterday we served 1,425 children with the curbside meals!! Thank you so much for your patience as our staff members work to hand out these meals.

The FHS Ninth Grade Center - Frenship ISD saw more than 400 children come through their line. To help with volume, we've added a second line at that campus. We also made adjustments to the flow of traffic at Terra Vista Middle School - Frenship ISD. We're hoping these changes can help get you and your families in and out faster!

We loved seeing our students' smiling faces and getting the sweet messages of encouragement. We'll see you again out there at noon!

More information on the curbside pickup: https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1702892&type=d&pREC_ID=1864739

post_text:
üö® Frenship Offers Curbside Meals to ALL Childrenüö®

Starting Monday, March 23rd, Frenship ISD will offer curbside meal pickup at six locations. In order to serve our entire community, any child age 18 or younger, regardless if they are a Frenship student, can pick up breakfast and lunch Monday through Friday.

The free grab-and-go meals will be available from 12:00 p.m. to 1:30 p.m. Monday through Friday until further notice. Each child will be provided two meals at the time of pickup each day. This includes lunch for that day and breakfast for the following morning. The child must be present to receive the meals.

The six pickup locations include:
- FHS Ninth Grade Center - Frenship ISD
- Legacy Elementary - Frenship ISD
- North Ridge Elementary - Frenship ISD
- Terra Vista Middle School - Frenship ISD
- Westwind Elementary - Frenship ISD
- Willow Bend Elementary - Frenship ISD

More Information: https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1702892&type=d&pREC_ID=1864739

Today Texas Governor Greg Abbott issued an executive order impacting schools across Texas.

Frenship staff will begin working from home on March 23rd to prepare for remote learning lesson plans. Spring Break remains extended one week for students, and they will be provided remote learning options only beginning March 30th.

*EDIT: We know that every family situation is different. We have dedicated staff members who are working hard to sort out the details of what remote learning will look like. Each Frenship family will be getting a personal call from us next week so we can assess each of your learning needs. We don't have all the answers right now, but we hope to give you more details next week.

More details here: https://www.frenship.net/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1702892&type=d&pREC_ID=1844819

post_text: We are so proud of our very own Dr. Michelle McCord on being recognized as one of the 2020 YWCA of Lubbock Women of Excellence. She was honored at the 32nd Annual Women of Excellence banquet last night where she celebrated with family, friends and the eight other honorees from Lubbock. Dr. McCord was nominated by Frenship ISD and the Frenship Foundation for Leadership, and she was sponsored by George and Linda McMahan. She embodies the Frenship Way and leads by example showing us we can "Seek Perfection ... Capture Excellence."

Today we celebrate the invaluable contributions of our team of Frenship ISD Diagnosticians who ensure each Frenship student has what they need to succeed!

Texas Governor, Greg Abbott, proclaims this week as Educational Diagnosticians Week and said, "For some children, learning new things and succeeding in their classes is a smooth process. For others, additional or specialized instruction is necessary for their success. When young Texans need a greater helping hand, educational diagnosticians play a vital role."

Thank you to an incredible team for all you do!

TWENTY-TWO. That's how many Frenship students will compete in the SkillsUSA State competition! Through hands-on, real world experience, these students are taking what they learned in their CTE courses and showing the STATE how Frenship's programs are successful!

These students competed in various competitions related to law enforcement, construction trades, automotive tech, and production/media.

See who is going to state: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1167226

The purpose of the event is to inform parents who will have 6th graders in the 2020-2021 school year about middle school schedules and course selections. Administrators and staff will be available to answer questions and help families make decisions about opportunities offered in middle school.

Frenship Athletics
February 25 at 11:22 PM ¬∑

Whew! What a night! Congratulations to BOTH the Tiger Boys and Girls Basketball teams!
üêØ üèÄ üí™

Tiger Girls won their Regional Quarterfinal game over EP Pebble Hills 74-44 to advance to their fourth Regional Tourney EVER! They'll face Cedar Hill Friday night at 8pm in Fort Worth at the Wilkerson-Greines Activities Center.

But did they drive home? No! They went to cheer on the boys up the road in Monahans!

The Tiger Boys took down EP Coronado 47-43 for the Bi-District Championship! They'll face Haltom in the Area Round. #TigerPride #FrenshipNation

üößTRAFFIC ALERTüöß

Heads up Frenship Families - starting tomorrow morning (Tuesday, February 25) you may experience traffic changes along Marsha Sharp near 82nd Street in Wolfforth. Construction crews will be switching MSF traffic onto the inside (passing) lanes. This will close the westbound MSF exit ramp to 82nd Street near Bennett Elementary. The exit will be closed after tomorrow morning‚Äôs commute and is expected to remain closed for most of the day.

*This means you will NOT be able to exit 82nd Street to pick up your children tomorrow afternoon, and may cause traffic delays for Bennett, FHS, NGC and FMS families*

TxDOT anticipates the traffic switch to last about four days ‚Äì two days for each direction of traffic. After the switch is done, the westbound 82nd Street exit ramp will remain open. During the construction, drivers should be on the lookout for various entrance and exit ramp closures along MSF in Wolfforth.
________________________________________
READ MORE: https://www.txdot.gov/inside-txdot/media-center/local-news/lubbock/003-2020.html#.XlPt3UY5w5U.twitter

post_text:
Congratulations to Frenship's Jacob Lierman! He received Lubbock Christian University's Young Alumnus of the Year Award! When you take a look at Mr. Lierman's accomplishments, it's easy to see why he was chosen.

His teaching and mentorship has led Frenship students to thrive on stage. Under his direction, One Act Plays have received four district championships, seven bi-district championships, four area championships, one regional championship and one state appearance. He has led students to 11 district championships throughout his entire career. Right now, 40 of his former students are currently in top theatre programs across the country and three have performed on Broadway!!

Read More: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1167124

It's Career and Technical Education Month, and what better way to celebrate than to have our students explore their future careers! This Monday, about 50 students traded in their day off to take part in a job shadow day! We even had some students continue the job shadow day today at City Bank (since they were closed on Monday)!

‚ÄúWe have 8-10 years of school ahead of us and because of the job shadow today, I am confident the years of schooling will be worth it,‚Äù said Jenny Pham, a senior who job shadowed at Key Animal Clinic. ‚ÄúCTE courses have been helpful! I was not as surprised as I thought I would be today because we have learned some of the basics in class.‚Äù

#CTEMonth
Read More: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1167024

post_text:
It's #NationalLoveYourPetDay ... but really we'll take any opportunity to show off Frenship K9 Lily! While she may not be a "pet", this four legged partner is a narcotics detection K9 for our secondary schools. She also enjoys putting on educational presentations across our District! She's been a part of the Frenship Family since October of 2019 and her handler, Lt. Amy Penn has been with us for 14 years!

A few of her favorite things are her ball, visiting with students, stuffed animals, and and being sassy with her partner (see picture #2 with her side eye üòÜ)

During the February school board meeting, Legacy Elementary - Frenship ISD students and staff gave a special surprise to Lubbock Area United Way members for their generous donation of nearly 900 books to Frenship kindergarten and first grade classes! United Way is on mission to provide books to every community in Lubbock and the South Plains.This donation was part of a grant they received from First Books and OMG Books for more than $17,000.

post_text:
How cool is this?! Yesterday, our Westwind students got to meet some interns who work at NASA's Johnson Space Center!

NASA intern Geraldo Cisneros, a Frenship graduate, led the presentation. We LOVED the message he shared: "Always keep looking up and never lose that desire to explore!"

Catch the full story in next week's Tiger Tales!
shared_text:
Westwind Elementary - Frenship ISD
February 18 at 6:26 PM ¬∑

NASA at Westwind

Geraldo Cisneros, father of two students at Westwind, is an intern at NASA this semester working in computer programing. Mr. Cisneros came to Westwind today to teach our students about NASA and some upcoming missions to the moon and later to MARS through photos, videos and even video conferencing with other NASA interns who were at the Johnson Space Center at the time. Those interns talked with us about what each of them were working on for NASA. The students were fascinated with learning about NASA and the future missions - some even hoping they can be an integral part some day. One thing that touched the students the most was that the group of astronauts who would be going to Mars are in elementary school right now. It could be one of the students in the room. The students could also be the engineers, programmers, AR/VR specialists, and other jobs that don't exist yet to help the mission to Mars or other missions.

post_text:
What an honor! Members of the YWCA of Lubbock stopped by our school board meeting last night to recognize Frenship Superintendent Dr. Michelle McCord!

Dr. McCord is one of only nine women across Lubbock to receive the 2020 YWCA Women of Excellence Award for her dedication, achievements and lasting impact on the community. McCord, along with the other eight esteemed women, will be celebrated during a program on March 12 to recognize their achievements in excellence within their respective careers and professions.

We are proud to have a leader who continually pushes our students and staff to 'Seek Perfection and Capture Excellence'!

Culinary, Auto Tech, Construction, Media Broadcast, Health Sciences, Engineering... the opportunities are endless in Frenship's Career and Technical Education program! Nearly 2,800 Frenship students are enrolled in at least one of the 85 CTE courses. But it's more than just a grade - last year 108 students earned industry certifications before graduating!

Learn more about how our Frenship is preparing students for high-wage, high-demand, and high-skilled careers:

#CTEMonth #CareerandTechnicalEducation

UPDATE Feb 5th: All Frenship ISD classes are cancelled today, February 5, due to icy conditions. Stay safe everyone!

*This also means any extracurricular activities, practices and events are also cancelled today.

---------
All Frenship ISD campuses will delay the start of school two hours tomorrow, February 5, due to inclement weather. Buses are scheduled to run a regular route two hours later than normal. Faculty and staff are asked to report to their campus as quickly and safely as possible to prepare for students arrival.

The District will continue to communicate any additional changes via call outs, Frenship ISD Facebook and Twitter pages, and here on the website.

It's National School Counselor Appreciation Week and we thought this story was the perfect example of how Frenship counselors go above and beyond to create safe, relaxing, stress free environments for our students to clear their heads!

Westwind Elementary - Frenship ISD's counselor Mrs. Chapman created a 'Mindfulness Room' for the students to take a moment, breathe, listen to some soothing music and just take a load off to balance their school day. ‚ÄúI just want to be proactive and provide as many kids with the tools they need to cope their feelings," said Mrs. Chapman.

Check out the full story: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1159366
#NSCW2020 #MindfulnessMatters

February is CTE Month, and Frenship ISD is thankful for community partnerships with organizations like Workforce Solutions South Plains and Lubbock Economic Development Alliance.

Over the past four years, LEDA and Workforce Solutions have gifted Frenship ISD with a total of $151,370 towards our CTE programs at Frenship High School to allow our students the best technology and machinery to learn and succeed.

Thank you for your continuous support of our students!

We're pretty excited and can't wait to cheer them on!

Thank you, Texas Farm Bureau, for providing our students with this fun activity!

We want to give a big shoutout to our community partners! George and Linda McMahan along with the Lubbock Economic Development Alliance are helping to launch INCubatoredu at Frenship High School! This program is based on an innovative curriculum to teach entrepreneurship and will be offered to FHS students next year. Through this program, students will be able to start their own business and learn how to be successful!

Thank you for your generous donations and dedication to helping our students succeed! Read more: https://www.frenship.net/apps/news/article/1151431

post_text:
Legacy Elementary fifth grade students are investigating Earth's changes under different circumstances like weathering, erosion and deposition.

They used a water stream table to understand how deltas are formed, a salt block to focus on erosion, ice blocks to represent glaciers and sand and straws to show how wind can create sand dunes. Hands-on activities are some of the best!
text:
Legacy Elementary fifth grade students are investigating Earth's changes under different circumstances like weathering, erosion and deposition.

post_text:
Frenship Alumnus, Omar Haney, currently serves in the military at Sheppard Air Force Base as a Pilot, where he flies the T-38 Talon.

He has been selected to be a USAF Fighter Pilot and will be flying the F-16 at various locations across the world in the coming years and requested a Frenship flag to take on his journey.

‚ÄúFrenship ISD had a profound influence on my life, and I imagine that effect has resonated with many other Frenship alum.‚Äù-V/R Lt. Haney

Thank you for your service, Lt. Haney! Once a Tiger, always a Tiger.
text:
Frenship Alumnus, Omar Haney, currently serves in the military at Sheppard Air Force Base as a Pilot, where he flies the T-38 Talon.

He has been selected to be a USAF Fighter Pilot and will be flying the F-16 at various locations across the world in the coming years and requested a Frenship flag to take on his journey.

‚ÄúFrenship ISD had a profound influence on my life, and I imagine that effect has resonated with many other Frenship alum.‚Äù-V/R Lt. Haney

Thank you for your service, Lt. Haney! Once a Tiger, always a Tiger.

post_text:
Second-grade students at Oak Ridge Elementary grabbed their passports and travelled to six foreign countries to learn about unique traditions and how the holidays are celebrated in different parts of the world!

They tried many different foods like butter cookies from Germany, tamales from Mexico, ginger snaps from Sweden, pomegranates from Greece and Sorrel from Trinidad. What a great way to explore the rest of our world!

post_text:
Why is the 2020 Census important to schools?

The 2020 Census count impacts the federal funds that communities receive each year for programs and services that are critical for schools, students, and younger children, such as:
-Special education, Head Start, after-school programs, and classroom technology.
-Food assistance, including free and reduced-price school lunches.
-Maternal and child health programs.

Help your community and apply today at www.2020census.gov/jobs
